channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 14 May
item.description: NZ entered alert level 2 after seven weeks of lockdown restrictions as the government prepares to unveil a Budget like no other. Follow RNZ's live updates.

item.title: Screen industry poised to play role in economic recovery
item.description: Wellington company Weta Digital is one of the few major visual effects facilities around the world to remain open, with Covid-19 hitting the industry hard overseas.

item.title: Covid-19: Shared workspace firms prepare for level 2, hotels offer day rentals
item.description: It is the end of working from home for many people and offices have been working out how to get their areas ready for level 2, while hotels are allowing day rentals as an option for those who want to keep the distance.

item.title: Funerals could take similar approach to tangihanga under new rules
item.description: Funeral directors say level 2 restrictions could mean families host multiple ceremonies on the same day, in an attempt to accommodate more than 50 people saying farewell to their loved ones.

item.title: Homicide inquiry launched over death of woman in West Auckland
item.description: A woman was found dead at a property in Henderson, West Auckland.

item.title: Ministry of Health says influenza vaccine demand surpasses supply
item.description: The Ministry of Health says the current supply would have been more than enough in an ordinary year, however, the pandemic had caused demand for influenza vaccinations to soar.

item.title: Nurses infected with Covid-19: Union calls for external investigation after review's findings
item.description: A nurses union says the situation that resulted in seven Waitākere Hospital nurses infected with the virus should trigger a WorkSafe investigation.

item.title: Covid-19: Kiwi scientist helps World Health Organisation in pandemic response
item.description: An Auckland scientist is preparing a briefing paper for the World Health Organisation that highlights cultural and social problems that may arise as governments try to control the spread of the virus.

item.title: Police trial of facial recognition technology 'a matter of concern' - Andrew Little
item.description: Minister of Justice Andrew Little says he does not know what police used the controversial facial recognition software in the trial for.

item.title: Unemployment figures fail to show 'hidden' jobless
item.description: A Canterbury man who cannot find work or access a benefit says he is part of a growing group of New Zealanders whose unemployment is hidden from any official figures.

item.title: The humble crumble helps keep Wanaka restaurant afloat in face of Covid-19
item.description: A Wanaka restaurant owner asked for support to save his business in the face of Covid-19 - and a humble Kiwi classic is helping save the day.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened on May 13
item.description: On the eve of alert level 2, there's been a change in heart for funeral rules, a push for housing investment, and concerns about demand on food banks.

item.title: DHB deputy boss apologises to nurses over Covid-19 outbreak
item.description: Checkpoint - Three nurses at Waitākere hospital likely contracted Covid-19 on a stressful day when a patient died and others were sick and confused, Waitematā DHB says.

item.title: Alert level 2 regional travel: Planes, ferries running but buses, trains stay shut down
item.description: Ferries are running, Air NZ will distance passengers, bus company InterCity has cancelled all trips until 29 May, and all long-distance tourist rail will remain shut down.

item.title: No physical distancing on school buses at level 2
item.description: The Ministry of Education says there is no room on school buses for physical distancing when services resume under lockdown level 2.

item.title: Police appeal for public's help in investigating death of man found at Evans Bay
item.description: Police are asking the public's help to try and understand the last movements of a man whose body was found at Evans Bay yesterday.

item.title: Oil company liquidation could leave ship idle
item.description: When New Zealand oil company Tamarind Taranaki went into liquidation in November last year, it left the government holding a big fat oily baby.

item.title: Up to 50 people to be allowed at funerals and tangihanga
item.description: Up to 50 people will be allowed at funerals and tangihanga if strict public health measures are in place, the government has announced. Watch a live media conference here.
